text: All the world's a stage, And all the men and women merely players; They have their exits and their entrances,
author: SS

text: And one man in his time plays many parts, His acts being seven ages. At first, the infant, Mewling and
author: SS

text: puking in the nurse's arms. Then the whining schoolboy, with his satchel And shining morning face, creeping like snail Unwillingly
author: SS

text: to school. And then the lover, Sighing like furnace, with a woeful ballad Made to his mistress' eyebrow. Then a
author: SS

text: soldier, Full of strange oaths and bearded like the pard, Jealous in honor, sudden and quick in quarrel, Seeking the
author: SS

text: bubble reputation Even in the cannon's mouth. And then the justice, In fair round belly with good capon lined, With
author: SS

text: eyes severe and beard of formal cut, Full of wise saws and modern instances; And so he plays his part.
author: SS

text: The sixth age shifts Into the lean and slippered pantaloon, With spectacles on nose and pouch on side; His youthful
author: SS

text: hose, well saved, a world too wide For his shrunk shank, and his big manly voice, Turning again toward childish
author: SS

text: treble, pipes And whistles in his sound. Last scene of all, That ends this strange eventful history, Is second childishness
author: SS

text: and mere oblivion, Sans teeth, sans eyes, sans taste, sans everything.
author: SS
